content: The Act titled "Protecting U.S. Missile Defense Information Act of 2012" limits funds for providing Russia with missile defense technology. The Act "Protecting U.S. Missile Defense Information Act of 2012" restricts Department of Defense funds for sharing classified missile defense technology or data with Russia for fiscal years 2012 and 2013. The Act "Protecting U.S. Missile Defense Information Act of 2012" limits Department of Defense funds for sharing missile defense technology with Russia in fiscal years 2012 and 2013. The Act limits Department of Defense funds for sharing missile defense technology with Russia in fiscal years 2012 and 2013. The technology or technical data must be protected, and specific details of Russian missile defense technology provided to the United States must be disclosed, along with the status of discussions between the two countries. The President must provide written certification. The Act restricts Department of Defense funds for sharing missile defense technology with Russia in fiscal years 2012 and 2013. The President must provide written certification that granting Russia access to such technology includes an agreement to prohibit access by other countries, will not enable the development of countermeasures to US missile defense systems, and will ensure equitable access for the US to Russian missile technology. The Act restricts Department of Defense funds for sharing missile defense technology with Russia in fiscal years 2012 and 2013. The President must provide written certification that granting Russia access to such technology includes an agreement to prohibit access by other countries, will not enable the development of countermeasures to US missile defense systems, and will ensure equitable access for the US to Russian missile technology. The limitation applies to the use of funds after the enactment of the Act, and reports and certifications must be submitted in unclassified form to appropriate congressional committees. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives, as defined in this section. SEC. 3. INTERNATIONAL AGREEMENTS RELATING TO MISSILE DEFENSE. Sense of Congress is that any missile defense cooperation agreement with Russia through NATO should be approved by Senate or Congress. A new section is added to the US Code regarding international agreements on missile defense. In accordance with the Resolution of Advice and Consent to Ratification of the New START Treaty, any agreement or amendment limiting US missile defense capabilities must be approved by the Senate or authorized by Congress. Annual notification is required by January 31 each year. The President must annually notify Congress by January 31 regarding whether the Russian Federation has acknowledged the US's right to enhance missile defense capabilities and if any treaty negotiations with Russia involved discussions on limiting US missile defense capabilities. The Russian Federation proposed including restrictions on missile defense capabilities, military capabilities in space, and conventional prompt global strike capabilities in a treaty with the United States. They also suggested reducing the number of non-strategic nuclear weapons deployed in Europe. The New START Treaty is defined as the Treaty between the United States and Russia on Measures for the Further Reduction and Limitation of Strategic Offensive Arms. The text discusses defense technology cooperation agreements between the United States and the Russian Federation, stating that funds for implementing such agreements cannot be used until 60 days after the President transmits the agreement to the congressional defense committees. The text defines a defense technology cooperation agreement as a cooperative agreement related to research and development. It also includes a clerical amendment to the table of sections. The text discusses a limitation on funds for travel expenses related to missile defense negotiations with Russia until a draft agreement is transmitted to congressional committees. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives.
